chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: All right.  So I could sort of see that for hospitalization.  I'm not sure why it's true for the ICU,  because if you don't have anybody at home to take care  of you when you get sick, it seems reasonable

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: that you'd be more likely to wind up in the hospital.  But I don't know why you'd wind up in intensive care.  Yeah?  Isn't it possible that those are also like single people  are probably younger than married people?

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And those are probably younger than widowed people.  Yes.  Yeah, that's probably also right.  Yep.  OK.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: So here's an interesting question,  a little bit related to something  you'll see on the next problem set.  So could we predict in-hospital mortality  from just these demographic features?

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: So I'm using a tool in language called R.  This is a general linear model.  And I've set it up to do basically logistic regression.  And it says I'm predicting whether you  die in the hospital based on these demographic factors.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And it turns out that the only ones that are highly  significant are age.  So that's not surprising that older people are more likely  to die than younger people.  It's generally true.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And if I'm unable to obtain your ethnicity  or I don't know your ethnicity, then you're  more likely to die.  I have no clue why that might be the case.  And other things are not as significant.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: So if you speak Spanish or English,  you're slightly less likely to die.  You see a negative contribution here.  And if you speak Russian, you're slightly less likely to die.  But it's significant not at the p equal 0.05 level,

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: but it is at the p equal 0.06 level.  And marriage doesn't seem to make much difference  in predicting whether you're going to die or not.  Now, remember, this is ICU patients.  And we're looking at in-hospital mortality.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Yeah.  AUDIENCE 2 For ethnicity, can they  learn that at any point during this day  or just right at the beginning?  Or do you know?

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Because I don't know.  I don't know.  Because it could be that unable to obtain  means that they died before we could ask them.  No, because there wouldn't be that many of those people,

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: I think.  There are not that many people who  don't live past the intake interview.  And they do ask them.  Unless they've gone into maintenance

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: and in bad shape to do it.  Yeah, that would be an example.  But I don't think you'd see enough such people  to show up statistically.  OK.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Well, so I've already mentioned that there's  this problem of having moved from CareVue to MetaVision  just in the MIMIC database.  But of course, this is a much bigger problem  around the country and around the world,

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: because every hospital has its own way of keeping records.  And wouldn't it be nice if we had standards?  And of course, there's this funny phrase,  the wonderful thing about standards  is that there are so many to choose from.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: So for example, if you look at prescriptions  in the MIMIC database, here are two particular prescriptions  for subject number 57139 admitted on admission ID 155470.  And so they have the same start date, but different end dates.  One is a prescription for Tylenol acetaminophen.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And the other is for clobetasol propionate 0.05% cream.  That's a skin lotion thing for, I think  it's a steroid skin cream.  So if you look in the BI's database,  they have their own private formulary code

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: where this thing is a set 325, and this thing is clob.05C30.  And if you look, there's also something  called a GSN, which is some commercial coding  system for drugs, maybe having to do with who their drug  supplier is at the hospital.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And these have different codes.  There's the National Drug Code, which  is an FDA-assigned nine-digit code that  specifies who made the drug, what form it's in,  and what's its strength.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And so you get these.  Then there's a human-readable description  that says Tylenol comes in 325 milligram tablets,  and this clobetasol comes in 30 gram tubes.  And the dose is supposed to be 325 to 650, i.e.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: one to two tablets measured in milligrams.  The dose here is one application, whatever that is.  I don't know what the 0.01 means.  And this is a tablet, and that's a tube.  And this is taken orally, and that's

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: administered on the skin.  So this is a local database.  AUDIENCE 2 For a doctor, they just get the package,  and then this is all registered?  PETER SZOLOVITSZ At most hospitals, that's true now.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: It wasn't true when the MIMIC database  started being collected.  And the BI was relatively late in moving  to that compared to some of the other hospitals in the Boston  area.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Each hospital has its own desiderata  for what it thinks is most important,  and I think the BI just didn't prioritize it  as much as some of the other hospitals.  So then I said, well, if you look at prescriptions,

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: how often are they given?  So remember, we have about 60,000 ICU stays,  and so isoasmotic dextrose was given 87,000 times  to various people.  Sodium chloride, 0.9% flush.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Do you know what that is?  Have you ever had an IV?  So periodically, the nurse comes by  and squirts a little bit of stuff in the IV  to make sure that it hasn't clogged up.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: That's what that is.  Insulin, SW, I don't know, salt water?  I don't know what SW is.  Magnesium sulfate, dextrose 5 in water.  Furosemide is a diuretic.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Potassium chloride replenishes potassium  that people are often low on.  And then you go, so why is there this D5W and that D5W?  And that's probably some data error in the system.  One of them has an NDC code associated with it,

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: and the other one doesn't, but probably should.  Yeah?  AUDIENCE 2 I'd actually like to ask,  do zeros mean that they're standard across hospitals,  or just that we don't have the data?

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: The NDC code should be standard across the country,  because those are FDA-assigned codes.  But not every hospital uses them.  And for the ones that say zero, I'm  not sure why they're not associated

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: with the code in this hospital's database.  OK.  Next most common, you see normal saline, 0.9% sodium chloride.  So that was the same stuff as the flush solution,  but this time not being used for flush.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: Metoprolol is a beta blocker.  Here's another insulin, this time with an NDC code, et  cetera.  I love bag and vial.  So these are not exactly medications.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: A bag is literally like a baggie that they put something into,  and a vial is literally something  that they put pills in.  And why is that in the database?  Because they get to charge for it.

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: And I don't know what the charge is,  but it wouldn't surprise me if you're  paying $5 for a plastic bag to put something in.  OK.  So if we say, well, how many pharmacy orders

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: are there per admission at this hospital?  And the answer is a lot.  So if you look at, it's a very long-tailed distribution,  goes out to about 2,500.  But you see, if I blow up just the numbers up to about 200,

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: there's a very large number of people  with two prescriptions filled, and then a fairly declining  number with more.  And then it's a very long tail.  So can you imagine 2,500 things prescribed for you

chunks.title: part.003.mp3
chunks.text: during a pharmacy order?
